articles.headline: Shares of Vonage Fall 13% on Debut
articles.snippet: Consumers may love Internet phone service, but investors are having second thoughts about the company that took it into the mainstream.

articles.headline: The Check Is Not in the Mail
articles.snippet: Insurance companies' tardiness or refusal to pay medical claims may add as much as 15 to 20 percent in overhead costs for the nation's physicians.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies' tardiness or refusal to pay medical claims may add as much as 15 to 20 percent in overhead costs for the nation's physicians.

articles.headline: Levees Rebuilt Just in Time, but Doubts Remain
articles.snippet: Independent engineers say the level of protection the Army Corps has reached is still not as strong as New Orleans needs.
articles.abstract: Independent engineers say the level of protection the Army Corps has reached is still not as strong as New Orleans needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, May 22 — In a breathless finale that has been called one of this generation's greatest adventures in civil engineering, the Army Corps of Engineers has all but completed its repairs to this city's ruined levee system.

articles.headline: XM Radio Fans Can Record It if They Hear It
articles.snippet: To be filed under "Best Ideas of the Year": the Samsung Helix and its twin, the Pioneer Inno, tiny music players that are also XM satellite radio receivers.
articles.abstract: To be filed under "Best Ideas of the Year": the Samsung Helix and its twin, the Pioneer Inno, tiny music players that are also XM satellite radio receivers.

articles.headline: New Signs of a Slowing Economy in 2 Federal Reports
articles.snippet: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March, and durable goods orders fell 4.8 percent in April.
articles.abstract: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March, and durable goods orders fell 4.8 percent in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report yesterday that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a softening economy.

articles.headline: Some in Mexico See Border Wall as Opportunity
articles.snippet: The proposal in the United States to build a wall at its southern border is gaining traction in Mexico.
articles.abstract: The proposal in the United States to build a wall at its southern border is gaining traction in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, May 24  To build, or not to build, a border of walls? The debate in the United States has started some Mexicans thinking it is not such a bad idea.

articles.headline: The Return of Martha Stewart, the Civil Case
articles.snippet: A year after her release from prison, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations.
articles.abstract: A year after her release from prison, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must now confront again the insider trading accusations that turned her world upside down.

articles.headline: Hussein's Former Envoy Gushes With Adulation on Witness Stand
articles.snippet: Tariq Aziz, Saddam Hussein's former principal international envoy, testified that his old boss's actions were backed by law.
articles.abstract: Tariq Aziz, Saddam Hussein's former principal international envoy, testified that his old boss's actions were backed by law.

articles.headline: Senate Bill on Immigration to Set Up Clash
articles.snippet: A compromise Senate bill that would toughen border security and put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship emerged intact Wednesday from more than a week of impassioned debate. Its advance set up a showdown with the House over the most s...
articles.abstract: A compromise Senate bill that would toughen border security and put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship emerged intact Wednesday from more than a week of impassioned debate. Its advance set up a showdown with the House over the most substantial overhaul of immigration law in 20 years.     After eight days of amendments and fiery arguments about national identity, the Senate voted 73 to 25 to limit further debate on the bill, suggesting that it had broad bipartisan support. The Senate also defeated several last-ditch efforts to derail the legislation, and members of both parties predicted that it would pass on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24 - A compromise Senate bill that would toughen border security and put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship emerged intact Wednesday from more than a week of impassioned debate. Its advance set up a showdown with the House over the most substantial overhaul of immigration law in 20 years.

articles.headline: Levees Rebuilt Just in Time, but Doubts Remain
articles.snippet: In a breathless finale that has been called one of this generation's greatest adventures in civil engineering, the Army Corps of Engineers has all but completed its repairs to this city's ruined levee system.      With just days to go before the b...
articles.abstract: In a breathless finale that has been called one of this generation's greatest adventures in civil engineering, the Army Corps of Engineers has all but completed its repairs to this city's ruined levee system.      With just days to go before the beginning of the hurricane season, the corps' $800 million effort has even improved the system in many ways, engineering experts say, with tougher concrete flood walls, brawny new canal gates and more than 150 miles of new or repaired levees.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, May 22 - In a breathless finale that has been called one of this generation's greatest adventures in civil engineering, the Army Corps of Engineers has all but completed its repairs to this city's ruined levee system.

articles.headline: The Return of Martha Stewart, the Civil Case
articles.snippet: A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must now confront again the insider trading accusations that turned her world upside down.      The three-year-old civil case against her is resuming. C...
articles.abstract: A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must now confront again the insider trading accusations that turned her world upside down.      The three-year-old civil case against her is resuming. Contesting the Securities and Exchange Commission accusations, as opposed to a negotiated settlement, would help give Ms. Stewart the opportunity to not only clear her name but also to win back her title as chairwoman and chief executive of the company she founded, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must now confront again the insider trading accusations that turned her world upside down.

articles.headline: House Leaders Demand Return of Seized Files
articles.snippet: The constitutional clash pitting Congress against the executive branch escalated Wednesday as the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House demanded the immediate return of materials seized by federal agents when they searched the office of a...
articles.abstract: The constitutional clash pitting Congress against the executive branch escalated Wednesday as the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House demanded the immediate return of materials seized by federal agents when they searched the office of a House member who is under investigation in a corruption case.     The demand, by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, and Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, underscored the degree of the anger generated among members of both parties on Capitol Hill by the search on Saturday night at the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana, who has been accused of accepting bribes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24 - The constitutional clash pitting Congress against the executive branch escalated Wednesday as the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House demanded the immediate return of materials seized by federal agents when they searched the office of a House member who is under investigation in a corruption case.

articles.headline: Some in Mexico See Border Wall as Opportunity
articles.snippet: To build, or not to build, a border of walls? The debate in the United States has started some Mexicans thinking it is not such a bad idea.     Nationalist outrage and accusations of hypocrisy over the prospect have filled airwaves and front pages...
articles.abstract: To build, or not to build, a border of walls? The debate in the United States has started some Mexicans thinking it is not such a bad idea.     Nationalist outrage and accusations of hypocrisy over the prospect have filled airwaves and front pages in Mexico, as expected, fueled by presidential campaigns in which appeals to national pride are in no short supply. But, surprisingly, another view is gaining traction: that good fences can make good neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, May 24 - To build, or not to build, a border of walls? The debate in the United States has started some Mexicans thinking it is not such a bad idea.

articles.headline: It's Dixie Chicks vs. Country Fans, but Who's Dissing Whom?
articles.snippet: Kelefa Sanneh Critic's Notebook on Dixie Chicks, who are being snubbed by country music fans because of singer Natalie Maines comments against Pres George W Bush just prior to invasion of Iraq; notes that many fans now see group as being against S...
articles.abstract: Kelefa Sanneh Critic's Notebook on Dixie Chicks, who are being snubbed by country music fans because of singer Natalie Maines comments against Pres George W Bush just prior to invasion of Iraq; notes that many fans now see group as being against Southern culture that is core of country music audience; holds that instead of fighting for their old fans, Dixie Chicks seem to be dismissing them; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Academy of Country Music awards on Tuesday night, the host, Reba McEntire, made an unfunny joke. "If the Dixie Chicks can sing with their foot in their mouths, surely I can host this sucker," she said. The setup was pretty awkward. And when you stopped to think about it, the punch line really wasn't one. But none of that mattered. The line earned one of the night's most enthusiastic ovations.

articles.headline: Shares of Vonage Fall 13% on Debut
articles.snippet: Consumers may love Internet phone service, but investors are having second thoughts about the company that took it into the mainstream.     In their first day of trading yesterday, shares in Vonage, the country's leading Internet phone provider, f...
articles.abstract: Consumers may love Internet phone service, but investors are having second thoughts about the company that took it into the mainstream.     In their first day of trading yesterday, shares in Vonage, the country's leading Internet phone provider, fell nearly 13 percent below the initial offering price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers may love Internet phone service, but investors are having second thoughts about the company that took it into the mainstream.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Hussein's Former Envoy Gushes With Adulation on Witness Stand
articles.snippet: Nobody in Saddam Hussein's inner circle was more tirelessly reverential toward him while he was in power than Tariq Aziz, who is said to have been in the habit of saluting the telephone when Mr. Hussein called.     So it was little surprise on Wed...
articles.abstract: Nobody in Saddam Hussein's inner circle was more tirelessly reverential toward him while he was in power than Tariq Aziz, who is said to have been in the habit of saluting the telephone when Mr. Hussein called.     So it was little surprise on Wednesday when Mr. Aziz, 70, became the first senior member of the old ruling elite to testify for Mr. Hussein at his trial on charges of crimes against humanity. Nor did Mr. Aziz depart from form: In an hour on the witness stand, Mr. Aziz, once Mr. Hussein's principal international envoy and now an inmate in an American military prison outside Baghdad, offered extenuating arguments for Mr. Hussein's actions that kept his old boss smiling genially from the dock.

articles.headline: XM Radio Fans Can Record It if They Hear It
articles.snippet: TO be filed under Best Ideas of the Year: Imagine a tiny music player, smaller than an iPod, that's also an XM satellite radio receiver. When you hear a song you like -- even if it's halfway over -- one press of a button records it from the beginn...
articles.abstract: TO be filed under Best Ideas of the Year: Imagine a tiny music player, smaller than an iPod, that's also an XM satellite radio receiver. When you hear a song you like -- even if it's halfway over -- one press of a button records it from the beginning.      Meet the Samsung Helix (and its twin, the Pioneer Inno): a tiny, well-designed $400 radio that not only lets you enjoy satellite radio in the car, at home or when you're jogging, but also plays back your own MP3 files and up to 750 songs that you've recorded from the satellites.

articles.headline: New Signs of a Slowing Economy in 2 Federal Reports
articles.snippet: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report yesterday that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a soft...
articles.abstract: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report yesterday that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a softening economy.     But the numbers did little to reassure investors hoping that the economic data would encourage the Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates when it meets next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report yesterday that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a softening economy.

articles.headline: The Check Is Not in the Mail
articles.snippet: Few things rankle a doctor more than an insurance company's saying it cannot find a claim for medical services. Particularly when there is even a signed return receipt to document delivery of the bill.      ''We actually had the little green card ...
articles.abstract: Few things rankle a doctor more than an insurance company's saying it cannot find a claim for medical services. Particularly when there is even a signed return receipt to document delivery of the bill.      ''We actually had the little green card to show who signed for the dang thing,'' said Elizabeth Wertz, chief executive of the Pediatric Alliance, a large group of Pittsburgh doctors. ''We sent it by certified mail. The insurance company said they didn't have it.''
